awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Low Cost Technologies to Improve the Quality of 3D Scanning
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops a new mathematical framework, algorithms, and optical designs to increase the resolution and precision of line and area 3D scanners, and to minimize the hardware cost.  Combining simple optical design techniques and novel mathematical formulations, this project builds the next generation of low cost high resolution 3D scanner systems based on active illumination and 3D triangulation.  The project designs, fabricates, and demonstrates prototype 3D scanners based on the new technologies. The project integrates research with education. Courses taught by the principal investigator on a regular basis provide the necessary mathematics, software, and practical details to design and build 3D scanners using off-the-shelf low cost semiconductor lasers, small LED projectors, and web-cams, as well as digital geometry processing software. Undergraduate and graduate students learn in these courses to design and build low cost 3D scanners based on the technologies being developed in this project. By significantly lowering the cost of high resolution 3D scanning systems, the technology, software and methods being developed in this project have significant impact in the multiple applications in computer vision, computer graphics, and robotics.  

The research studies a new mathematical formulation for 3D optical triangulation based on interval arithmetic, where 3D points are only determined within certain bounds along the camera rays, and multiple measurements are used to tighten these bounds.  The project introduces the "Line Segment Cloud" as an alternative surface representation, and as a tool to visualize the measurement errors within the proposed framework.  The project develops new variational surface reconstruction methods with line segment constraints tailored to line segment clouds.  Enabled by the new formulation, the project is constructing: 1) novel laser line and structured light super-resolution 3D scanners, where the projectors are mounted on small displacement motion platforms; 2) structured light area 3D scanners where the different 3D patterns are projected by fixed non-coaxial LED slide projectors, and neither DLP or LCD projector engines are used; and 3) super-resolution 3D scanners based on volume carving, optimized for existing line and area based 3D scanners, where camera and projector are rigidly mounted with respect to each other.  The project is also developing techniques to design laser line projectors optimized for optical triangulation using inexpensive optical components, where the thickness of the projected line is significantly reduced and the depth of field is increased. The project develops new calibration methods and performance metrics to evaluate these technologies.

por.por_cntn:
3D scanning technologies based on 3D optical triangulation estimate the location of each 3D point as the intersection of a camera ray and a projector plane.  A number of low cost desktop laser line 3D scanners have been introduced to the 3D printer market over the last few years.  The resolution of these 3D scanners is not adequate for applications in art, entertainment, industrial inspection, reverse engineering, medicine, forensics, and many other advanced applications. Industrial laser line 3D scanners used primarily for inspection applications, and built with higher quality laser line generators, produce more accurate measurements, but are much more expensive and not designed for general 3D scanning applications. Structured light area 3D scanners using 2D pattern projector engines are significantly more expensive and complex than laser line 3D scanners.
This project developed a new mathematical framework, new algorithms, and novel optical designs to increase the resolution and precision of line and area 3D scanners, and to minimize the hardware cost. Combining simple optical design techniques and a novel mathematical formulation based on interval arithmetic, this project developed a number of novel low cost high resolution 3D scanner systems based on active illumination and 3D triangulation.  Prototype 3D scanners based on the proposed novel technologies were designed, fabricated, and demonstrated. Experiments were performed to show that the proposed technologies are competitive with the state of the art.
The project developed a new mathematical formulation for 3D optical triangulation based on interval arithmetic, where 3D points are only determined within certain bounds along the camera rays, and multiple measurements are used to tighten these bounds.  The project introduced the "Line Segment Cloud" as an alternative surface representation, and as a tool to visualize the measurement errors within the proposed framework.  The project developed new variational surface reconstruction methods with line segment constraints tailored to line segment clouds.  Enabled by the proposed formulation, the project constructed: 1) novel laser line and structured light super-resolution 3D scanners, where the projectors are mounted on small displacement motion platforms; 2) structured light area 3D scanners where the different 3D patterns are projected by fixed non-coaxial LED slide projectors, and neither DLP or LCD projector engines are used; and 3) super-resolution 3D scanners based on volume carving, optimized for existing line and area based 3D scanners, where camera and projector are rigidly mounted with respect to each other.
The project also developed techniques to design laser line projectors optimized for optical triangulation using inexpensive optical components, where the thickness of the projected line is significantly reduced and the depth of field is increased. Laser line generator as well as DLP and LCD projector engines, which use lenses to focus the patterns, are intrinsically limited for 3D scanning applications due to depth of field constraints. The project introduced "Light Field Sources" as a new mathematical model to describe extended light sources where each emitter point has a different directional distribution with a dominant direction, and developed several optical design techniques to construct light field sources.  The project used light field sources to design focus-free pattern projectors.  All the new proposed 3D scanning methods required novel calibration methods, and performance metrics, which we were also developed within the project as well.
Courses taught by the PI on a regular basis provide the necessary mathematics, software, and practical details to design and build 3D scanners using off-the-shelf low cost semiconductor lasers, small LED projectors, and web-cams, as well as digital geometry processing software.  During the duration of this project, undergraduate and graduate students learned in these courses to design and build low cost 3D scanners based on the technologies developed within this project.
By significantly lowering the cost of high resolution 3D scanning systems, the technology, software and methods being developed in this project will have significant impact in the multiple application domains listed above.
